channel.title: NYT > U.S. News

item.title: HUD opens discrimination investigation into a Muslim development in Texas.
item.description: A project, including homes and a mosque, has drawn attacks from Republican Texas officials. The Justice Department closed a similar inquiry into the development last year.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: The East Plano Islamic Center in Plano, Texas, last year. The Department of Housing and Urban Development has opened an investigation into a large housing complex centered by the mosque.

item.title: Boneless Wings Are Still Wings, Judge Rules
item.description: A Chicago man filed a lawsuit in 2023 against Buffalo Wild Wings, arguing that it had engaged in false advertising of its boneless wings. A judge said the claim “has no meat on its bones.”
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:credit: Josh Haner/The New York Times
item.media:description: A reasonable person would understand that boneless wings are chicken nuggets coated in Buffalo sauce, a judge said on Tuesday.

item.title: House Plans to Vote on Air Safety Bill After Report on Deadly D.C. Crash
item.description: Lawmakers could vote as early as next week on legislation aimed at avoiding another collision like the one that killed 67 people near Reagan National Airport last year.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The wreckage of American Airlines Flight 5342 was pulled from the Potomac River last year.

item.title: How a Stray Quote of Jesse Jackson’s Led to a Rupture Between Black and Jewish Voters
item.description: The candidate’s reference to New York as “Hymietown” helped tank his 1984 presidential campaign and eroded a longstanding alliance.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Mahler
item.media:credit: Paul Sakuma/Associated Press

item.title: To One Chicago Resident, Jesse Jackson Was Simply a Friendly Neighbor
item.description: At the Jackson home in Chicago, people paid quiet tributes to a man they said was groundbreaking but also ‘very grounded.’
item.dc:creator: Leigh Giangreco
item.media:credit: Kamil Krzaczynski/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Delores Brown placing flowers in front of Jesse Jackson’s house in Chicago on Tuesday.

item.title: Jesse Jackson’s Death Arrives at a Crucial Moment for Black Political Power
item.description: There are more Black senators than ever before, but a major Supreme Court ruling could reduce Black representation in the House.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators outside the Supreme Court in October, during oral arguments in a case that could significantly weaken the Voting Rights Act.

item.title: In Memphis, mourning for the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who kept coming back.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Brad J. Vest for The New York Times
item.media:description: Theresa Jackson, left, and her fiancé, Hoyt Zanders, paid their respects to Jesse Jackson outside the Lorraine Motel in Memphis on Tuesday.

item.title: Jesse Jackson’s Hometown Remembers Him as a ‘Superstar’
item.description: Mr. Jackson often spoke about Greenville, S.C., in his speeches, returning home several times to fight for change — and for a slice of his favorite banana cream pie.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina and Nick Madigan
item.media:credit: Greenville News-USA TODAY NETWORK vis Imagn Images
item.media:description: Jesse Jackson at Sterling High School's homecoming game in 1958, in Greenville, S.C.

item.title: Trump Bets on Diplomacy Without Diplomats
item.description: President Trump’s most trusted envoys, Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, are at the center of the Iran and Ukraine negotiations.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Nathan Howard for The New York Times
item.media:description: Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner in Israel last October.

item.title: Jesse Jackson Changed Chicago. And It Changed Him.
item.description: Mr. Jackson, who spent much of his life in the city, died at his home there on Tuesday. “He ushered in new politics in Chicago,” one longtime organizer said.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Gary Settle/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jesse Jackson, wearing a hat and with his hands in the air, led a protest over trade union membership in Chicago in 1969.

item.title: Police Arrest Man Who Ran Toward the Capitol With a Loaded Gun
item.description: The 18-year-old arrested was wearing a tactical vest and carrying additional rounds of ammunition, the Capitol Police said. Congress was not in session, and no one was hurt.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Frantz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Capitol Police said nobody was hurt and there was no threat to the area after a man with a gun was arrested on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Indicts Captain of an Oil Tanker the Coast Guard Chased for Weeks
item.description: The charges include falsely flying a Guyanese flag and failing to obey a Coast Guard order to halt the ship for boarding by U.S. forces.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Seamus Hughes and Christiaan Triebert
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Russell Cheyne/Reuters
item.media:description: The Marinera, an oil tanker previously known as the Bella 1, off the coast of Scotland on Jan. 14, after being seized by the U.S. Coast Guard following a weekslong chase around the Atlantic.

item.title: White House Shrugs Off Lutnick’s Epstein Ties
item.description: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick has acknowledged traveling to Jeffrey Epstein’s island and meeting him on another occasion.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Yuri Gripas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary, is among the Trump administration officials whose names appear in the Epstein files.

item.title: The president of the National Urban League recalls his long friendship with Jackson.
item.dc:creator: Audra D. S. Burch

item.title: House Republican Faces Backlash to Islamophobic Post Suggesting He Prefers Dogs to Muslims
item.description: Representative Randy Fine had responded to a Palestinian organizer by saying that “the choice between dogs and Muslims is not a difficult one.”
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Randy Fine, a Jewish first-term congressman, often makes Islamophobic or otherwise bigoted remarks on social media.

item.title: California Wealth Tax Opponents Intensify Efforts Before Bernie Sanders Visit
item.description: The opponents’ latest moves include online ads tied to Gov. Gavin Newsom, a crypto-related push to raise money and competing ballot measures.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times; Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times

item.title: White House Rejects Democrats’ Offer for Deal to Reopen D.H.S.
item.description: With Congress in a weeklong recess, there was little sign of progress toward a deal to fund the Department of Homeland Security.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, during a Senate hearing last Thursday.

item.title: Republicans Reach Deal With Democrats in N.C. Voter Rolls Case
item.description: The agreement, which still must be approved by a judge, would end a lawsuit brought by the Republican National Committee that challenged the state’s handling of its voter registration list.
item.dc:creator: Tim Balk
item.media:credit: Cornell Watson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Republicans had argued that state officials had for years accepted registration applications with missing information and had failed to inform applicants that they needed to provide it. They had requested that voters with missing information be purged from the rolls.

item.title: Republicans, Braced for Losses, Push More Voting Restrictions in Congress
item.description: Legislation that would require proof of citizenship to register to vote was only the beginning as the G.O.P. presses to sharply limit voting in line with President Trump’s false claims of widespread fraud.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ballots being counted in Los Angeles County in 2024. Representative Bryan Steil, Republican of Wisconsin, is pushing ahead with a bill that would ban universal voting by mail and prohibit counting ballots received after Election Day.

item.title: N.B.A. All-Star Game’s Map of France Leaves Something Out: 800 Years
item.description: Introducing the French player Victor Wembanyama was a map that hearkened back to the Capetian realm of the 12th century.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Allen Berezovsky/Getty Images
item.media:description: Victor Wembanyama of France at the N.B.A. All-Star Game on Sunday.

item.title: Jackson’s ‘Keep Hope Alive’ Speech in 1988 Was a Call for Social Justice and Unity
item.description: Though he didn’t win the Democratic nomination for president in either year, Jesse Jackson’s moving speeches at the conventions called on the party to care more about the marginalized.
item.dc:creator: James C. McKinley Jr. and Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: John Duricka/Associated Press

item.title: U.S. Kills 11 in Boat Strikes in Pacific and Caribbean
item.description: It was the first time in the campaign against people the United States accuses of drug smuggling at sea that American forces blew up boats on both sides of the Panama Canal in the same day.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: Tricia McLaughlin, Forceful Defender of Trump’s Immigration Agenda, Is Leaving DHS
item.description: Ms. McLaughlin was one of the most prominent voices in the administration defending President Trump’s mass deportation campaign.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Magana/Associated Press
item.media:description: Tricia McLaughlin is expected to depart at the end of the month.

item.title: Mourners remember Jackson outside his organization’s Chicago headquarters.
item.dc:creator: Robert Chiarito

item.title: Al Sharpton, Bernice King and Trump Among Tributes to Jesse Jackson
item.description: In states including South Carolina, where Mr. Jackson was born, and Illinois, officials also ordered flags to be flown at half-staff.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, left, with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, in 2022.

item.title: Ed Crane, Who Built a Libertarian Stronghold, Dies at 81
item.description: Starting with $500,000 in seed money from Charles Koch, Mr. Crane made the Cato Institute the nation’s pre-eminent libertarian think tank.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel

item.title: The Jesse Jackson Speech That Helped Redefine the Democratic Party’s Base
item.description: In his 1984 speech at the Democratic National Convention in San Francisco, Mr. Jackson argued for a more diverse coalition for the party.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson delivered a speech at the Democratic National Convention after failing to secure the party’s nomination for president in 1984.

item.title: Hegseth Is Said to Have Ordered Pentagon Spokesman’s Firing
item.description: The spokesman, Col. Dave Butler, worked for the Army chief of staff.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth arriving for a classified briefing at the Capitol in Washington in January.

item.title: Jackson’s Rainbow PUSH Coalition Was a Powerful Advocate for His Politics
item.description: The campaigning organization Jesse Jackson founded became the vehicle he used to push for social justice and change policy.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Joshua Lott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rev. Jesse Jackson at a Rainbow PUSH Coalition rally in Chicago, in 2007.

item.title: A Holiday High School Game Is Shattered by a Fatal Assault
item.description: At a hockey rink in Pawtucket, R.I., shots rang out, leaving two people dead, in addition to the shooter. The police chief said it was a family matter that exploded in public.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Jacey Fortin
item.media:credit: Cj Gunther/Reuters
item.media:description: Police officers raced to the arena in Pawtucket when mayhem erupted.

item.title: How Jesse Jackson Inspired Generations of Black Democrats
item.description: Mr. Jackson’s presidential campaigns created a pathway for scores of Black Democrats to run for office, with many making historic leaps to prominent offices.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Chester Higgins, Jr./The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Jesse Jackson greeting him in what was then North Tarrytown, N.Y., during his 1988 presidential campaign. He finished second, but showed that a Black candidate could make a serious run for a major party’s nomination.

item.title: Jesse Jackson’s Bid for President in 1988 and Other Pivotal Moments
item.description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson entered the national spotlight during the civil rights movement and ran for president twice. He also courted controversy while in the public eye.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Neal Boenzi/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, center, leading a protest in 1970 in New York for Operation Breadbasket, an economic development campaign.

item.title: Read the Statement From Jesse Jackson’s Family
item.description: Mr. Jackson “died peacefully,” surrounded by his family, the statement said. It did not say where Mr. Jackson died or the cause of his death.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times
item.media:description: Rev. Jesse Jackson during a voter-registration drive in New York City in 1984, part of what his family called his efforts to elevate the voices of the voiceless.

item.title: Jesse Jackson had a difficult early life in Greenville, S.C.
item.dc:creator: Peter Applebome

item.title: Obama Took On Recession, Health Care and Iraq. What He Didn’t See Coming Was Trump.
item.description: A new set of oral history interviews documents how Barack Obama and his advisers missed the shifting mood of the country that would ultimately replace him with a successor they considered a “con man,” “clown” and “laughingstock.”
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: Here’s more on his life.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: Jesse Jackson: A Life in Pictures
item.description: The civil rights leader was one of the country’s most influential Black figures.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times

item.title: An M.L.K. Landmark Is Revived at a Tense Moment for Historical Sites
item.description: The Masonic lodge that served as the home base for Dr. King’s activism will soon be open to visitors. It had long been considered endangered.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas
item.media:credit: Alyssa Pointer for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Sought Vast Budget Cuts. Congress Granted Few.
item.description: In a series of deals over the past three months, lawmakers rejected some of the president’s most aggressive attempts to whittle down the government.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Congress has left intact a large set of federal programs that the White House tried to slash or eliminate this fiscal year.

item.title: Military Veterans Are Among Americans Protesting ICE
item.description: Veterans have taken part in demonstrations against the federal crackdown on illegal immigration in Minnesota. “I believe in the institutions,” one said.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman, Talya Minsberg and Jazmine Ulloa
item.media:credit: Ben Brewer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Kendall, who served in the U.S. Air Force, outside the federal building in Minnesota that has been a center of protest.

item.title: Are You a New Yorker With a Unique Parking Situation? We Want to Hear It.
item.description: We want to hear from New Yorkers who rent driveways or have surprising parking garage arrangements.
item.dc:creator: Ronda Kaysen
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Jesse Jackson, Charismatic Champion of Civil Rights, Dies at 84
item.description: An impassioned orator, he was a moral and political force, forming a “rainbow coalition” of poor and working-class people and seeking the presidency. His mission, he said, was “to transform the mind of America.”
item.dc:creator: Peter Applebome
item.media:credit: Keith C. Meyers/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson acknowledged the applause of delegates at the 2000 Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles.
